history.content: I think everything looks fine, except soph second semester. 126 and 127 are tough classes that you will need to spend a lot of time on, and 61c will require a lot of time, so I'd recommend taking a humanities class instead of 61c if you plan on doing anything outside of academics (research, etc.). I might consider putting off a junior year first sem class to senior year, although I'm not really sure because I can't comment on the difficulty of Math 104 or EE128.

children.subject:
Thank you so much for the advice! I jist have a few questions to follow up with.

1. Is it recommended to have taken 61C before/concurrently with 106A?

2. Is it feasible to move 106A to soph first sem and 128 to soph second sem without any other adjustments? (Soph second sem starts to look too crazy with 126, 127, 128, and 61C) If I need to make adjustments, do you have any ideas? Maybe swap 127 and 188 in my current proposed plan?)

Oncr again, I really appreciate the help.

You'll want to make some adjustments. 61C is totally unnecessary for 106A. The only prereqs are 61B, 16B, Phys 7A (or high school physics). I'd definitely move some classes later. 110, 106A, 170, 120 is pretty hard but maybe doable since 106A is the only project course (I might move 110 or 170 up a semester). 126, 127, 128, 61C is way too much. I'd def switch 188 with one of them, or just move something to your newly freed slots in junior year.

As a math major, I think 106A will be especially interesting to you, since it's a real-life use case for some of the more abstract math concepts. Sastry will be teaching in the fall, and he's a very math-y professor.

This is very late, but I'd recommend trying to take a project/controls course earlier than Junior year. Getting hands-on experience early is very nice from an intuition-building perspective, and it'll give you early information on whether controls is the path for you. 106A could be taken first sem sophomore year (though I'd probably leave 106B to junior year), and 128 could possible be taken in spring sophomore year. 188 is also pretty light/hands-on/fun, so taking it earlier might be nice. 

Also, I highly recommend TAing. It's been one of the best parts of my academic career.

history.content:
Hi, I'm a freshman intended CS / Applied Math double major taking EE16B, 70, and 61B right now and doing alright in them I guess. I'm really interested in pursuing areas of control theory and robotics. Right now I have a vague plan for my next few semesters as

Sophomore year first sem:

EE 120

Math 110

CS 170

CS 370? (might move this, I'm interested in TAing something eventually so will have to take at some point)

Sophomore year second sem:

EE 126 + 127 (I heard this could be pretty bad, but hopefully by this time I already gain a decent amount of mathematical maturity and can handle)

CS 61C (could also be bad in combo with above 2)

Junior year first sem:

EE 106A

CS 188

Math 104

EE 128

Junior year second sem:

EE 106B

CS 189

Math 185

I guess senior year I'll finish my math upper divs and take some grad classes like EE 221A, EE 222, or some computer vision stuff. Another thing to keep in mind is that I'll need to throw in breadths here too. I'll probably P/NP those. Last thing is that I know it would make my life a lot easier if I did some classes over this summer, but I'm probably going back home (out of state) and attempting to satisfy both R1's and maybe breaths too at CC. Future summers may be possible, but I also want to consider internships/research as well.

Well thanks for taking the time to look this over. I would really appreciate any and all suggestions and critique for this. I know from looking at this that I'm giving myself some sucky semesters, so please let me know if this isn't feasible.
history.subject: When should I take EE 120, 126, 127, 128 + CS 170, 188, 189 + Math + Others...
